text.content: As a developer starting a blog, these thoughts might feel familiar:

rich_text.plain_text: As a developer starting a blog, these thoughts might feel familiar:

text.content: "Do I need to look up Markdown syntax again..."

rich_text.plain_text: "Do I need to look up Markdown syntax again..."

text.content: "Why is it so complicated to upload just one image?"

rich_text.plain_text: "Why is it so complicated to upload just one image?"

text.content: "The code block styling just doesn't feel right..."

rich_text.plain_text: "The code block styling just doesn't feel right..."

text.content: "I want a truly 'my own' blog without being tied to a platform..."

rich_text.plain_text: "I want a truly 'my own' blog without being tied to a platform..."

text.content: Being locked into a platform can feel especially restrictive. You want to customize things your way, but you're confined within limited features. üîí

rich_text.plain_text: Being locked into a platform can feel especially restrictive. You want to customize things your way, but you're confined within limited features. üîí

text.content: But what if you could solve all these problems using Notion, the tool you already use every day?

rich_text.plain_text: But what if you could solve all these problems using Notion, the tool you already use every day?

rich_text.plain_text: Using the open-source project NotionPresso, you can:

rich_text.plain_text: Keep using Notion's familiar editing environment

text.content: Plus, being open-source means no cost concerns. You can even contribute your own improvements.

rich_text.plain_text: Plus, being open-source means no cost concerns. You can even contribute your own improvements.

text.content: This guide will walk you through the entire process of creating and managing a blog with NotionPresso. From writing in Notion to SEO optimization and commenting features - let's create your perfect blog! üöÄ

text.content: NotionPresso is a React component library designed to replicate Notion's block-based editing experience on the web. Through its hierarchical structure, it can accurately render all Notion elements.

rich_text.plain_text: NotionPresso is a React component library designed to replicate Notion's block-based editing experience on the web. Through its hierarchical structure, it can accurately render all Notion elements.

text.content: The top-level container component that provides Notion-style typography and layout. This component provides style context for all Notion elements within it, so it must be positioned at the top level.

rich_text.plain_text: The top-level container component that provides Notion-style typography and layout. This component provides style context for all Notion elements within it, so it must be positioned at the top level.

text.content: Displays the post's cover image. Automatically applies the same ratio and style as Notion's cover images. Automatically hides if no image is present.

rich_text.plain_text: Displays the post's cover image. Automatically applies the same ratio and style as Notion's cover images. Automatically hides if no image is present.

text.content: Container for main content. Automatically applies appropriate padding and margins, and supports responsive layout. Provides optimal readability on mobile devices.

rich_text.plain_text: Container for main content. Automatically applies appropriate padding and margins, and supports responsive layout. Provides optimal readability on mobile devices.

text.content: Renders the post title. Applies the same typography and spacing as Notion titles and automatically generates SEO-optimized HTML structure.

rich_text.plain_text: Renders the post title. Applies the same typography and spacing as Notion titles and automatically generates SEO-optimized HTML structure.

text.content: Automatically recognizes and renders various Notion block types. Supported block types:

rich_text.plain_text: Automatically recognizes and renders various Notion block types. Supported block types:

rich_text.plain_text: : Maintains component structure that reflects Notion's document structure

text.content: Run the following command in your terminal to fetch the Notion page data:

text.content:
# Run this in your project root directory

# Install NotionPresso CLI (first time only)
npm install -g @notionpresso/cli

# Fetch Notion data
npresso --page [page URL or ID] --auth [Notion Integration token]

# Run this in your project root directory

# Install NotionPresso CLI (first time only)

# Fetch Notion data

text.content: Since Cloudflare Pages operates in a serverless environment, some Node.js features might not be compatible by default. To resolve this, you need to activate the

rich_text.plain_text: Since Cloudflare Pages operates in a serverless environment, some Node.js features might not be compatible by default. To resolve this, you need to activate the

text.content:
flag in your Cloudflare Pages project settings.
This flag ensures that Node.js-based features work properly in Cloudflare Pages.

rich_text.plain_text:
flag in your Cloudflare Pages project settings.
This flag ensures that Node.js-based features work properly in Cloudflare Pages.

text.content: When you push code to your GitHub repository, Cloudflare Pages will automatically start the build and deployment process. The build command and output settings are handled automatically based on your framework selection.

rich_text.plain_text: When you push code to your GitHub repository, Cloudflare Pages will automatically start the build and deployment process. The build command and output settings are handled automatically based on your framework selection.

text.content: After code modifications or setting changes, pushing a new commit to GitHub will trigger automatic redeployment. With the

rich_text.plain_text: After code modifications or setting changes, pushing a new commit to GitHub will trigger automatic redeployment. With the

text.content: flag enabled, Node.js compatibility issues will be resolved during deployment.

rich_text.plain_text: flag enabled, Node.js compatibility issues will be resolved during deployment.

text.content: After the build completes, you can access your site through the URL provided by Cloudflare. You can also set up a custom domain to run your site on your preferred domain.

rich_text.plain_text: After the build completes, you can access your site through the URL provided by Cloudflare. You can also set up a custom domain to run your site on your preferred domain.

text.content: For projects using Node.js features, make sure to redeploy after enabling the compatibility flag to ensure all features work correctly.

text.content: Adding Comments to Your Blog with Giscus

rich_text.plain_text: Adding Comments to Your Blog with Giscus

text.content: Want to add a comment section where visitors can share their thoughts and interact? With Giscus, you can easily implement a commenting system based on GitHub Discussions. This guide will walk you through installing and integrating Giscus into your blog step by step.

rich_text.plain_text: Want to add a comment section where visitors can share their thoughts and interact? With Giscus, you can easily implement a commenting system based on GitHub Discussions. This guide will walk you through installing and integrating Giscus into your blog step by step.

text.content: Giscus is a comments system powered by GitHub Discussions. Using Giscus, you can easily add commenting functionality to your blog or website using GitHub accounts for authentication.

rich_text.plain_text: Giscus is a comments system powered by GitHub Discussions. Using Giscus, you can easily add commenting functionality to your blog or website using GitHub accounts for authentication.

text.content: You can install the Giscus app to GitHub

rich_text.plain_text: You can install the Giscus app to GitHub

text.content: To install Giscus, you need to connect the Giscus app to your GitHub repository. Here are the installation steps:

rich_text.plain_text: To install Giscus, you need to connect the Giscus app to your GitHub repository. Here are the installation steps:

text.content: Go to the Giscus installation page and click the "Configure" button.

rich_text.plain_text: Go to the Giscus installation page and click the "Configure" button.

text.content: Configure access permissions for the repository where Giscus will be used.

rich_text.plain_text: Configure access permissions for the repository where Giscus will be used.

text.content: To use Giscus, you need to enable Discussions feature in your repository. Follow these steps:

rich_text.plain_text: To use Giscus, you need to enable Discussions feature in your repository. Follow these steps:

text.content: This allows Giscus to use GitHub Discussions functionality.

rich_text.plain_text: This allows Giscus to use GitHub Discussions functionality.

text.content: After installing Giscus, follow these steps to display comments on your website.

rich_text.plain_text: After installing Giscus, follow these steps to display comments on your website.

text.content: You can easily configure this at

rich_text.plain_text: You can easily configure this at

text.content:
// Script example
<script src="<https://giscus.app/client.js>"
  data-repo="notionpresso/nextjs-blog-template"
  data-repo-id="R_kgDONDy8gg"
  data-category="Announcements"
  data-category-id="DIC_kwDONDy8gs4CjpSV"
  data-mapping="pathname"
  data-strict="0"
  data-reactions-enabled="1"
  data-emit-metadata="0"
  data-input-position="bottom"
  data-theme="preferred_color_scheme"
  data-lang="en"
  crossorigin="anonymous"
  async>
</script>

rich_text.plain_text:
// Script example
<script src="<https://giscus.app/client.js>"
  data-repo="notionpresso/nextjs-blog-template"
  data-repo-id="R_kgDONDy8gg"

  data-category-id="DIC_kwDONDy8gs4CjpSV"

  data-strict="0"
  data-reactions-enabled="1"
  data-emit-metadata="0"
  data-input-position="bottom"
  data-theme="preferred_color_scheme"
  data-lang="en"
  crossorigin="anonymous"
  async>
</script>

rich_text.plain_text: This script should be inserted in the appropriate location on your webpage.

text.content: In React projects, you can easily add Giscus using the

rich_text.plain_text: In React projects, you can easily add Giscus using the

text.content:
'use client'
import Giscus from "@giscus/react";

export default function Comment() {
  return (
    <Giscus
      id="comments"
      repo="notionpresso/nextjs-blog-template"
      repoId="R_kgDONDy8gg"
      category="Announcements"
      categoryId="DIC_kwDONDy8gs4CjpSV"
      mapping="pathname"
      strict="0"
      reactionsEnabled="1"
      emitMetadata="0"
      inputPosition="bottom"
      theme="preferred_color_scheme"
      lang="en"
      loading="lazy"
    />
  )
}
